Occipital lobe
questions.explanation: This clinical presentation—anterograde amnesia with preserved procedural learning—is the hallmark of hippocampal damage, famously demonstrated by patient H.M. (Henry Molaison): (1) The hippocampus is critical for consolidating new declarative (explicit) memories—both episodic (personal events) and semantic (facts). Bilateral hippocampal damage prevents formation of new declarative memories. (2) Procedural memory (motor skills, habits) depends on different structures: basal ganglia (particularly the striatum), cerebellum, and supplementary motor areas. These are intact in this patient. (3) Remote memories are preserved because they have already been consolidated into neocortical storage through systems consolidation—the hippocampus is needed for initial encoding and consolidation but not for long-term storage of remote memories. (4) This dissociation provides strong evidence for multiple memory systems in the brain with distinct neural substrates.

questions.question: Which brain region is the primary center for thermoregulation in mammals?
options: Cerebellum
Occipital lobe
Motor cortex
Preoptic area of the hypothalamus
questions.explanation: The preoptic area of the anterior hypothalamus is the primary thermoregulatory center. It contains: (1) Warm-sensitive neurons that increase firing rate when blood temperature rises, triggering cooling responses (vasodilation, sweating, panting). (2) Cold-sensitive neurons that respond to decreased temperature, triggering warming responses (vasoconstriction, shivering, non-shivering thermogenesis via brown adipose tissue). The hypothalamic thermostat compares core body temperature (sensed by central thermoreceptors) with a set point (~37°C in humans). Fever occurs when pyrogens (interleukins, prostaglandin E2) raise the hypothalamic set point—the body then generates heat to reach the new, higher set point. Antipyretics (aspirin, ibuprofen) reduce fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.

questions.question: Which type of glial cell lines the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord?
options: Oligodendrocytes
Astrocytes
Ependymal cells
Schwann cells
questions.explanation: Ependymal cells are ciliated epithelial cells that line the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. Functions include: (1) CSF circulation—their cilia beat in a coordinated manner to propel cerebrospinal fluid through the ventricular system. (2) Barrier function—ependymal cells form a partial barrier between CSF and brain tissue (though this barrier is more permeable than the blood-brain barrier). (3) Some ependymal cells in specific regions are modified as tanycytes, which have long processes extending into the hypothalamus and may function in neuroendocrine signaling. (4) The choroid plexus, which produces CSF, consists of specialized ependymal cells overlying capillaries in the ventricles.

questions.question: The blood-brain barrier (BBB) is formed primarily by brain capillary endothelial cells connected by tight junctions. However, certain brain regions called circumventricular organs (CVOs) lack a complete BBB. Why is this functionally important?
options: CVOs are vestigial structures with no current function
The lack of BBB in CVOs is a developmental defect that causes disease

CVOs such as the area postrema (vomiting center) and median eminence need direct access to blood-borne signals (hormones, toxins, osmolarity) to monitor blood composition and regulate homeostatic responses
CVOs require higher oxygen levels than other brain regions
questions.explanation: Circumventricular organs (CVOs) are specialized brain regions with fenestrated capillaries (lacking tight junctions) that allow direct chemical communication between blood and brain: (1) Sensory CVOs (detect blood-borne signals): Area postrema—detects blood-borne toxins and triggers vomiting (chemoreceptor trigger zone); Subfornical organ and organum vasculosum of the lamina terminalis (OVLT)—detect blood osmolarity and angiotensin II for fluid balance regulation. (2) Secretory CVOs (release hormones into blood): Median eminence—hypothalamic releasing hormones access the hypothalamic-hypophyseal portal system; Neurohypophysis (posterior pituitary)—releases oxytocin and ADH into blood; Pineal gland—secretes melatonin. (3) CVOs are strategically positioned to serve as "windows" between the blood and brain, enabling neuroendocrine regulation and homeostatic monitoring. Tanycytes (specialized ependymal cells) in CVOs help regulate which substances reach the brain.

questions.question: The concept of neurovascular coupling describes:
options: How blood vessels form in the embryonic brain
The mechanism by which neural activity triggers local increases in cerebral blood flow to provide oxygen and glucose to active brain regions
The connection between the heart and brain
How neurons grow along blood vessels
questions.explanation: Neurovascular coupling is the mechanism linking neural activity to local cerebral blood flow: (1) Active neurons and astrocytes release vasoactive molecules (nitric oxide, prostaglandins, potassium ions, adenosine). (2) These molecules dilate local arterioles, increasing blood flow to active brain regions within 1-2 seconds. (3) Astrocytes play a key intermediary role—their endfeet contact both synapses and blood vessels, converting neural signals to vascular responses. (4) This mechanism ensures that metabolically active brain regions receive adequate oxygen and glucose. Neurovascular coupling is the basis for fMRI BOLD signal and other hemodynamic brain imaging methods. Disruption of neurovascular coupling is implicated in Alzheimer's disease, stroke, and vascular dementia.

questions.question: Which brain structure serves as the primary relay for pain signals ascending from the spinal cord to the cerebral cortex?
options: Cerebellum
Thalamus (ventral posterolateral nucleus)
Hippocampus
Corpus callosum
questions.explanation: Pain (nociceptive) signals from the body travel via A-delta (fast, sharp pain) and C fibers (slow, dull pain) to the spinal cord dorsal horn. Second-order neurons cross the midline and ascend in the spinothalamic tract to the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus. From the thalamus, signals project to the somatosensory cortex (sensory-discriminative component) and to the anterior cingulate cortex and insula (affective-motivational component). The thalamus serves as the obligatory relay for ascending pain information. Other thalamic targets include the medial dorsal nucleus (projecting to prefrontal cortex) and intralaminar nuclei (projecting broadly to cortex for arousal).

questions.question: The hypothalamus, despite comprising less than 1% of brain volume, serves as a critical integrative center. Which of the following is NOT a function directly controlled by the hypothalamus?
options: Conscious language comprehension and speech production
Body temperature regulation via thermoreceptors and autonomic responses
Circadian rhythms via the suprachiasmatic nucleus
Regulation of food intake via hunger and satiety centers
questions.explanation: The hypothalamus is the master regulator of homeostasis and autonomic function: (1) Thermoregulation: The anterior hypothalamus (preoptic area) detects blood temperature and coordinates cooling responses; the posterior hypothalamus coordinates heating responses (shivering, vasoconstriction). (2) Circadian rhythms: The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) serves as the master circadian clock, receiving direct retinal input via the retinohypothalamic tract. (3) Feeding behavior: The arcuate nucleus contains NPY/AgRP (orexigenic) and POMC/CART (anorexigenic) neurons that integrate leptin, ghrelin, and insulin signals. (4) Additional functions: water balance (osmoreceptors, ADH release), reproductive function (GnRH), stress response (CRH to pituitary), autonomic nervous system coordination, and emotional behavior. Language comprehension (Wernicke's area) and speech production (Broca's area) are cortical functions of the left hemisphere, not hypothalamic.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about neurotransmitter systems in the brain are correct? (I) Dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra pars compacta project primarily to the dorsal striatum via the nigrostriatal pathway. (II) The locus coeruleus is the primary source of norepinephrine in the brain. (III) Serotonin is synthesized exclusively in the cerebral cortex. (IV) The nucleus basalis of Meynert provides the major cholinergic input to the cerebral cortex and degenerates in Alzheimer disease.
options: I and II only
I, II, and IV only
II and III only
I, II, III, and IV
questions.explanation: Evaluating each statement: (I) CORRECT: Substantia nigra pars compacta (SNpc) dopaminergic neurons project to the dorsal striatum (caudate and putamen) via the nigrostriatal pathway. Degeneration of these neurons causes Parkinson disease. (II) CORRECT: The locus coeruleus (LC) in the pons is the primary noradrenergic nucleus, with widespread projections to virtually all brain regions. LC activity increases with arousal, stress, and attention. (III) INCORRECT: Serotonin (5-HT) is synthesized primarily in the raphe nuclei of the brainstem (dorsal and median raphe), not the cortex. These neurons project widely throughout the brain and spinal cord. (IV) CORRECT: The nucleus basalis of Meynert (NBM) in the basal forebrain provides the major cholinergic innervation of the neocortex. Severe degeneration of NBM cholinergic neurons occurs in Alzheimer disease and contributes to cognitive decline—this is the basis for cholinesterase inhibitor therapy. Therefore I, II, and IV are correct.

questions.question: Neural oscillations (brain rhythms) recorded by EEG are classified by frequency bands. Alpha waves (8-13 Hz) are characteristically associated with:
options: Deep non-REM sleep
Active problem-solving and intense concentration
Relaxed wakefulness with eyes closed, and are suppressed (alpha blocking) when the subject opens their eyes or begins a cognitive task
Epileptic seizure activity
questions.explanation: Brain oscillations (neural rhythms) arise from synchronized activity of neuronal populations and are classified by frequency: (1) Delta (0.5-4 Hz): deep non-REM sleep (stages 3-4). (2) Theta (4-8 Hz): drowsiness, memory consolidation, hippocampal processing. (3) Alpha (8-13 Hz): relaxed wakefulness, particularly prominent over occipital cortex with eyes closed. Alpha blocking—suppression when eyes open or mental effort begins—was one of the first EEG phenomena described (Berger, 1929). (4) Beta (13-30 Hz): active thinking, focus, anxiety. (5) Gamma (30-100 Hz): attention, perception, consciousness binding. Neural oscillations reflect synchronization of local field potentials from excitatory and inhibitory neuronal populations and are critical for information processing, attention, and inter-regional communication.

questions.question: In an experiment, researchers lesion the left motor cortex of a rat. Which of the following behavioral outcomes would you predict, and why?
options: Impaired voluntary movement of the right side of the body because the corticospinal tract crosses (decussates) at the pyramidal decussation in the medulla, so the left cortex controls right-sided muscles
Paralysis of the left side of the body because motor cortex controls ipsilateral muscles
No motor deficits because the cerebellum compensates immediately
Bilateral paralysis because each motor cortex controls both sides
questions.explanation: Contralateral motor control via the corticospinal tract: (1) The primary motor cortex (precentral gyrus) contains upper motor neurons whose axons form the corticospinal tract. (2) At the medullary pyramids (pyramid decussation), approximately 85-90% of corticospinal fibers cross to the opposite side, forming the lateral corticospinal tract. (3) Therefore, the left motor cortex primarily controls voluntary movements of the right side of the body, and vice versa. (4) A left motor cortex lesion produces contralateral (right-sided) weakness or paralysis, particularly affecting distal limb muscles (fine motor control). (5) The remaining 10-15% of uncrossed fibers (anterior corticospinal tract) cross at segmental levels and primarily control axial/proximal muscles, providing some ipsilateral motor control. (6) Recovery may occur through: ipsilateral corticospinal projections, cortical reorganization (plasticity), or compensatory strategies via other motor pathways (rubrospinal, reticulospinal).

questions.question: A patient suffers a stroke that damages the left primary motor cortex. Which deficit would be expected?
options: Paralysis of the left side of the body
Loss of vision in both eyes
Paralysis of the right side of the body (contralateral), because motor pathways cross the midline in the medullary pyramids
Complete loss of hearing
questions.explanation: Damage to the left primary motor cortex produces contralateral (right-sided) motor deficits because the corticospinal tract (pyramidal tract) crosses the midline (decussates) at the medullary pyramids in the brainstem. Specifically: ~80-85% of corticospinal fibers cross at the pyramidal decussation, forming the lateral corticospinal tract that controls distal limb muscles contralaterally. The remaining ~15-20% do not cross and form the anterior corticospinal tract (controlling axial muscles). Therefore, left cortex damage → right body weakness/paralysis (contralateral hemiparesis/hemiplegia). The face is also affected contralaterally, as corticobulbar fibers to the lower face motor neurons cross similarly.

questions.question: The enteric nervous system (ENS), sometimes called the "second brain," contains approximately 200-600 million neurons. What evidence supports the ENS's ability to function autonomously from the central nervous system?
options: The ENS receives input from the vagus nerve
The ENS uses different neurotransmitters than the CNS

Isolated segments of intestine (denervated from the CNS) can still generate coordinated peristaltic contractions through local reflex circuits involving sensory neurons, interneurons, and motor neurons within the myenteric and submucosal plexuses
The ENS develops from mesoderm rather than neural crest
questions.explanation: The ENS demonstrates remarkable autonomy: (1) Structural independence: Complete reflex circuits exist within the gut wall—intrinsic primary afferent neurons (IPANs) detect mechanical and chemical stimuli, interneurons relay signals, and motor neurons control smooth muscle, secretion, and blood flow. (2) The peristaltic reflex (Bayliss and Starling, 1899): Even in completely denervated intestinal segments, distension triggers coordinated contraction oral to the stimulus and relaxation anal to it, propelling contents aborally. (3) The ENS uses >30 neurotransmitters (serotonin, acetylcholine, NO, VIP, substance P, etc.). (4) Two plexuses organize ENS circuits: myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus controls motility; submucosal (Meissner's) plexus controls secretion and blood flow. (5) While the ENS can function autonomously, it normally receives modulatory input from the CNS via the vagus nerve (parasympathetic) and sympathetic fibers. Hirschsprung disease, where ENS ganglia are absent from a segment of colon, demonstrates ENS necessity—the aganglionic segment cannot perform peristalsis.

questions.question: Glial cells (neuroglia) perform essential functions in the nervous system. Which glial cell type produces myelin in the central nervous system?
options: Oligodendrocytes
Schwann cells
Astrocytes
Microglia
questions.explanation: Oligodendrocytes produce myelin sheaths in the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord). A single oligodendrocyte can myelinate segments of multiple axons (up to ~50). In contrast, Schwann cells produce myelin in the peripheral nervous system, with each Schwann cell myelinating a single internode of one axon. Other glial cells: (1) Astrocytes—most abundant CNS glia, maintaining the blood-brain barrier, regulating extracellular K⁺ and neurotransmitter levels, providing metabolic support to neurons. (2) Microglia—resident immune cells of the CNS, derived from mesoderm (not neural crest), phagocytosing debris and pathogens. (3) Ependymal cells—line the ventricles, producing cerebrospinal fluid (along with choroid plexus epithelial cells).

questions.question: A neuroscientist wants to determine whether a specific brain region is necessary for a particular behavior in mice. Which approach provides the strongest evidence for necessity?
options: Functional MRI showing activation during the behavior

Reversible inactivation using optogenetics (halorhodopsin to silence neurons) or chemogenetics (DREADDs) during the behavior, showing the behavior is disrupted when neurons are silenced and restored when silencing is removed
Recording neural activity correlating with the behavior
Anatomical tracing showing connections between the region and motor areas
questions.explanation: To demonstrate that a brain region is necessary for a behavior requires a loss-of-function approach: if silencing the region disrupts the behavior, and removing the silencing restores it, the region is necessary. Modern techniques provide temporal precision: (1) Optogenetic silencing—express inhibitory opsins (halorhodopsin, archaerhodopsin) in specific neurons; light delivery silences them on a millisecond timescale. (2) Chemogenetics (DREADDs)—express modified receptors that respond only to an inert drug (CNO/DCZ); drug administration silences neurons for hours. These reversible approaches are superior to permanent lesions because: they avoid compensatory plasticity, allow within-subject controls, and can target specific cell types. Correlation (fMRI, electrophysiology) shows association but not causation.

questions.question: The prefrontal cortex is associated with executive functions. Which specific executive function is most impaired by damage to the prefrontal cortex?
options: Basic visual perception
Planning, decision-making, impulse control, and working memory
Reflexive withdrawal from painful stimuli
Heart rate regulation
questions.explanation: The prefrontal cortex (PFC) is the anterior portion of the frontal lobe, highly developed in primates and especially humans. PFC damage (as in the famous case of Phineas Gage) impairs: (1) Planning and goal-directed behavior. (2) Decision-making and judgment. (3) Impulse control and social behavior (particularly orbitofrontal/ventromedial PFC). (4) Working memory—the ability to hold and manipulate information temporarily (particularly dorsolateral PFC). (5) Cognitive flexibility—switching between tasks or strategies. (6) Attention and concentration. The PFC is the last brain region to mature (not fully myelinated until ~25 years old), which partly explains adolescent risk-taking behavior. PFC dysfunction is implicated in ADHD, schizophrenia, and addiction.

questions.question: The myelin sheath has gaps called nodes of Ranvier. What is the functional significance of nodes of Ranvier?
options: They provide sites for neurotransmitter release
They store calcium ions for synaptic transmission
They prevent action potentials from propagating
They enable saltatory conduction—action potentials jump between nodes, dramatically increasing conduction velocity
questions.explanation: Nodes of Ranvier are ~1 μm gaps between myelin segments (internodes ~1 mm long) where the axonal membrane is exposed and enriched with voltage-gated Na⁺ channels (~1,200/μm² at nodes vs. ~25/μm² under myelin). During saltatory conduction, current flows passively through the myelinated internode (low-resistance, high-capacitance insulation) and regenerates the action potential only at nodes. This dramatically increases conduction velocity (up to 120 m/s in large myelinated fibers vs. ~2 m/s in unmyelinated fibers of similar diameter) while reducing metabolic cost (fewer ions need to be pumped back). Demyelinating diseases (MS, Guillain-Barre) disrupt saltatory conduction.

questions.question: Synaptic vesicle release requires calcium influx. Which protein complex directly mediates the fusion of synaptic vesicles with the presynaptic membrane?
options: Clathrin coat proteins
Myosin motor proteins
Sodium-potassium ATPase
The SNARE complex (synaptobrevin/VAMP, syntaxin, and SNAP-25)
questions.explanation: The SNARE (Soluble NSF Attachment Protein Receptor) complex directly mediates synaptic vesicle fusion: (1) v-SNARE synaptobrevin (VAMP2) on the vesicle membrane interacts with t-SNAREs syntaxin-1 and SNAP-25 on the presynaptic membrane. (2) The four-helix SNARE bundle 'zips up' from N- to C-terminus, pulling the vesicle and plasma membranes together with sufficient force to drive membrane fusion. (3) Ca²⁺ influx through voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels triggers the final fusion step via synaptotagmin (the Ca²⁺ sensor), which binds Ca²⁺ and interacts with SNAREs and phospholipids. (4) After fusion, NSF and alpha-SNAP disassemble the SNARE complex for recycling. Tetanus and botulinum toxins are proteases that cleave specific SNARE proteins, blocking neurotransmitter release.

questions.question: Neurulation is the embryonic process that forms the neural tube. What congenital defect results from failure of the posterior neural tube to close?
options: Spina bifida
Anencephaly
Hydrocephalus
Cerebral palsy
questions.explanation: Spina bifida results from failure of the posterior (caudal) neural tube to close completely during the 4th week of human embryonic development. The severity ranges from: (1) Spina bifida occulta—incomplete vertebral arch closure with no herniation (often asymptomatic). (2) Meningocele—meninges protrude through the vertebral defect. (3) Myelomeningocele—spinal cord and meninges protrude, causing paralysis and loss of sensation below the defect. Anencephaly results from failure of the anterior (cranial) neural tube to close, causing absence of major brain regions (incompatible with life). Folic acid (vitamin B9) supplementation before and during early pregnancy reduces neural tube defect risk by ~70%, which is why folate fortification of grain products is mandated in many countries.

questions.question: The basal ganglia consist of several interconnected nuclei that modulate motor and cognitive functions. The primary input structure (receiving cortical afferents) and the primary output structure (projecting to the thalamus) are, respectively:
options: Globus pallidus (input), Caudate nucleus (output)
Thalamus (input), Cerebral cortex (output)
Subthalamic nucleus (input), Putamen (output)
Striatum/caudate-putamen (input), Globus pallidus internal segment/Substantia nigra pars reticulata (output)
questions.explanation: The basal ganglia circuit: (1) INPUT: The striatum (caudate nucleus + putamen) is the primary input structure, receiving glutamatergic projections from the entire cerebral cortex (somatotopic organization) and dopaminergic projections from the substantia nigra pars compacta. (2) Processing: Information flows through direct (striatum → GPi/SNr, facilitating movement) and indirect (striatum → GPe → STN → GPi/SNr, inhibiting movement) pathways. (3) OUTPUT: The globus pallidus internal segment (GPi) and substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr) are the primary output structures, sending GABAergic (inhibitory) projections to the thalamus (VA/VL nuclei), which then excites the motor cortex. At rest, GPi/SNr tonically inhibits the thalamus. Movement initiation involves disinhibition—the direct pathway suppresses GPi/SNr, releasing thalamic neurons to excite the cortex.

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about cerebrospinal fluid (CSF):
I. CSF is produced primarily by the choroid plexus in the brain ventricles
II. CSF cushions the brain against mechanical impact and provides buoyancy
III. CSF is reabsorbed into the venous blood through arachnoid granulations (villi)
IV. CSF has the same composition as blood plasma
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
questions.explanation: I. TRUE: CSF is produced (~500 mL/day in adults, ~150 mL total volume) by the choroid plexus—specialized ependymal cells with fenestrated capillaries in the lateral, third, and fourth ventricles. Active transport of ions (Na⁺, Cl⁻, HCO₃⁻) drives water movement into the ventricles. II. TRUE: CSF reduces the effective weight of the brain from ~1,400 g to ~50 g through buoyancy (Archimedes' principle), protecting against mechanical damage. III. TRUE: CSF is reabsorbed into venous blood via arachnoid granulations (villi) projecting into the superior sagittal sinus. Impaired reabsorption can cause hydrocephalus (CSF accumulation). IV. FALSE: CSF differs from plasma—it has lower protein concentration (~0.3% vs. ~7% in plasma), lower glucose, fewer cells, and a different electrolyte composition. The blood-CSF barrier at the choroid plexus selectively controls CSF composition.

questions.question: The octopus brain contains approximately 500 million neurons, with about two-thirds located in the arms rather than the central brain. What does this distribution suggest about octopus neural processing?
options: Significant autonomous local processing occurs in the arms, enabling independent motor control without requiring central brain commands for every movement
The central brain controls all arm movements directly
The arms function independently of the central brain at all times
Arm neurons are non-functional remnants
questions.explanation: The octopus nervous system is remarkable for its distributed architecture: (1) The central brain (supra- and subesophageal masses) handles higher-order processing, learning, and decision-making. (2) Each arm contains a brachial ganglion and extensive nerve cords with ~40 million neurons per arm. (3) Severed arms can still perform coordinated movements (grasping, walking), demonstrating autonomous local control. (4) This distributed architecture allows the central brain to issue high-level commands while arms handle the computational demands of controlling their flexible, boneless structure (infinite degrees of freedom). (5) This represents convergent evolution of complex nervous systems in a lineage (mollusks) very distant from vertebrates.

questions.question: A researcher uses the Morris water maze to test hippocampal-dependent spatial memory in mice. The maze consists of a circular pool of opaque water with a hidden platform. What is the key dependent variable that indicates spatial learning?
options: The latency (time) to find the hidden platform across training trials, and the time spent in the platform quadrant during probe trials
The speed at which the mouse swims
The color of the mouse's fur
The amount of water consumed by the mouse
questions.explanation: The Morris water maze assesses hippocampal-dependent spatial learning and memory: (1) During training—mice must learn the location of a hidden submerged platform using distal spatial cues (landmarks on the walls). The latency to find the platform decreases across trials, indicating spatial learning. (2) During probe trials—the platform is removed, and the time spent in the target quadrant (where the platform was located) vs. other quadrants indicates spatial memory. Mice with hippocampal lesions show no platform quadrant preference. Additional measures include: path length, search strategy analysis (random vs. directed), and reversal learning (platform moved to new location). The maze specifically tests allocentric spatial memory, which is hippocampus-dependent.

questions.question: The concept of 'excitotoxicity' refers to:
options: Neuronal death caused by excessive glutamate receptor activation, leading to calcium overload and activation of destructive enzymes
The toxic effects of inhibitory neurotransmitters
The damage caused by too many inhibitory synapses
Toxicity from excessive sleep
questions.explanation: Excitotoxicity is a major mechanism of neuronal death in stroke, traumatic brain injury, and neurodegenerative diseases: (1) During ischemia or injury, damaged neurons release excessive glutamate. (2) Excessive activation of NMDA and AMPA receptors causes massive Ca²⁺ influx. (3) Elevated intracellular Ca²⁺ activates destructive enzymes: calpains (proteases), phospholipases (membrane degradation), endonucleases (DNA fragmentation), and nitric oxide synthase (free radical production). (4) Mitochondrial Ca²⁺ overload triggers the mitochondrial permeability transition, releasing cytochrome c and initiating apoptosis. (5) The cascade propagates as dying neurons release more glutamate. This creates a feed-forward loop of neuronal death. Understanding excitotoxicity has guided therapeutic strategies for stroke (rapid reperfusion to limit glutamate release).

questions.question: The somatosensory cortex in the parietal lobe contains a topographic map of the body surface (somatotopic map). In this map, which body parts are disproportionately overrepresented?
options: The trunk and legs
The back and shoulders
The hands, fingers, lips, and tongue
All body parts are equally represented
questions.explanation: The somatosensory homunculus (cortical map) shows disproportionate representation of body parts based on their sensory innervation density, not physical size. The hands/fingers and face (lips, tongue) have extremely high receptor density and fine discriminative ability, so they occupy large cortical areas. The trunk and legs, despite their large physical size, have relatively sparse innervation and small cortical representation. This principle also applies to the motor homunculus in the primary motor cortex, where hand/finger and face/tongue areas are disproportionately large, reflecting the fine motor control required for manipulation and speech.

questions.question: The cerebellum receives two major excitatory inputs: mossy fibers and climbing fibers. How do these inputs differ in their origin and connectivity pattern?
options: They have identical origins and connectivity

Mossy fibers arise from diverse sources (pontine nuclei, spinal cord, vestibular nuclei) and diverge widely—each mossy fiber contacts many granule cells; climbing fibers arise exclusively from the inferior olive and each climbing fiber wraps around a single Purkinje cell, making hundreds of synaptic contacts
Both inputs synapse directly on Purkinje cells with equal strength
Climbing fibers arise from the cerebral cortex and mossy fibers from the thalamus
questions.explanation: The cerebellum has a highly stereotyped circuit architecture with two distinct excitatory inputs: (1) Mossy fibers: Arise from multiple sources—pontine nuclei (relaying cerebral cortex input), spinocerebellar tracts (proprioceptive), vestibular nuclei, reticular formation. They synapse on granule cells in the granular layer, which send parallel fibers through the molecular layer to contact Purkinje cell dendrites. One mossy fiber diverges to contact ~400 granule cells; each granule cell sends a parallel fiber contacting ~300 Purkinje cells. This creates a massive divergence/convergence network. (2) Climbing fibers: Arise exclusively from the inferior olive (contralateral). Each Purkinje cell receives input from exactly ONE climbing fiber (in adults), but that climbing fiber makes ~300 synaptic contacts climbing along the Purkinje cell dendritic tree. Climbing fiber activation produces a powerful "complex spike" (multiple spikelets). (3) Functional significance: Mossy fiber/parallel fiber input provides the "context" signal; climbing fiber input provides an "error" or "teaching" signal that drives cerebellar LTD at active parallel fiber-Purkinje cell synapses, enabling motor learning.

questions.question: The cerebellum receives input from multiple sources and integrates them to coordinate movement. Which describes the error-correction model of cerebellar function?
options: The cerebellum compares intended motor commands (from the cortex) with actual sensory feedback, computing error signals that refine ongoing and future movements
The cerebellum directly initiates voluntary movements
The cerebellum only processes vestibular information
The cerebellum stores long-term declarative memories
questions.explanation: The cerebellum functions as a comparator or error-correction system: (1) It receives copies of motor commands from the cerebral cortex (via pontine nuclei → mossy fibers). (2) It simultaneously receives sensory feedback about actual movement (from proprioceptors, vestibular system, visual system via inferior olive → climbing fibers). (3) Purkinje cells compute the discrepancy (error) between intended and actual movement. (4) Error signals are sent (via deep cerebellar nuclei) to the motor cortex and brainstem motor centers to adjust ongoing movements and update internal models for future movements. (5) This is the basis of motor learning—repeated practice reduces cerebellar error signals as movements become automatic. Cerebellar damage causes ataxia (uncoordinated movement), intention tremor, and dysmetria.

questions.question: Epilepsy is characterized by recurrent seizures caused by abnormal synchronous neuronal firing. Which mechanism is primarily responsible for seizure generation?
options: An imbalance between excitatory (glutamatergic) and inhibitory (GABAergic) neurotransmission, favoring excitation
Excessive serotonin release
Demyelination of peripheral nerves
Degeneration of the cerebellum
questions.explanation: Seizures result from an imbalance between excitation and inhibition in neural circuits, with excessive synchronous excitatory activity. Contributing mechanisms include: (1) Enhanced glutamatergic (excitatory) transmission—increased glutamate release, upregulation of AMPA/NMDA receptors. (2) Reduced GABAergic (inhibitory) transmission—decreased GABA synthesis, reduced GABA receptor function, loss of inhibitory interneurons. (3) Ion channel dysfunction—mutations in voltage-gated Na⁺, K⁺, or Ca²⁺ channels (channelopathies) can increase neuronal excitability. (4) Network-level mechanisms—abnormal circuit formation (e.g., hippocampal mossy fiber sprouting). Anti-epileptic drugs target these mechanisms: enhancing GABA (benzodiazepines, barbiturates), blocking Na⁺ channels (phenytoin, carbamazepine), or blocking glutamate receptors (perampanel).

questions.question: The concept of the 'grandmother cell' versus 'population coding' in neuroscience refers to how the brain represents complex stimuli. Which model is most supported by current evidence?
options: Individual neurons each respond to only one specific object (grandmother cell)
Complex stimuli are represented by patterns of activity across populations of neurons, with individual neurons participating in multiple representations (population coding)
Only motor neurons encode information
The brain does not encode information at all
questions.explanation: Population coding (distributed representation) is the dominant model: individual neurons respond to multiple related stimuli with different firing rates, and a stimulus is encoded by the pattern of activity across a population of neurons. Evidence: (1) Neurons in visual cortex respond to ranges of orientations, spatial frequencies, and locations, not single specific stimuli. (2) Population decoding algorithms can accurately predict stimulus identity or motor intention from population activity. (3) Sparse coding models suggest that a small subset of neurons is active for any given stimulus, balancing specificity with efficiency. However, some 'concept cells' in the human medial temporal lobe respond selectively to specific individuals or concepts (e.g., 'Jennifer Aniston neurons'), suggesting that some high-level representations approach the grandmother cell concept in a sparse coding framework.

questions.question: Synaptic pruning is an important developmental process in the nervous system. During postnatal brain development, synaptic density:
options: Remains constant from birth through adulthood

Initially increases dramatically (synaptogenesis), reaching a peak in early childhood, then decreases through activity-dependent elimination of unused synapses (pruning) during childhood and adolescence—with prefrontal cortex pruning continuing into the mid-20s
Continuously increases throughout life
Decreases from birth and never recovers
questions.explanation: Synaptic pruning follows a well-characterized developmental trajectory: (1) Synaptogenesis: After birth, synapse formation occurs at extraordinary rates (up to 40,000 new synapses per second in some brain regions during peak periods). Synaptic density peaks at different ages in different regions: visual cortex peaks around 8 months, prefrontal cortex around 3-4 years. (2) Pruning: Activity-dependent mechanisms selectively eliminate weak or unused synapses while strengthening active ones ("use it or lose it"). This follows Hebbian principles and involves: complement proteins (C1q, C3) tagging synapses for microglial phagocytosis, and proteasome-mediated degradation of postsynaptic scaffolding. (3) Regional timing: Sensory cortices mature earliest; prefrontal cortex pruning continues into the mid-20s, which has implications for adolescent decision-making, risk-taking, and the age of onset of schizophrenia (which may involve excessive pruning). (4) Result: Adult brains have approximately half the synaptic density of peak childhood levels, but remaining synapses are stronger and more efficient. (5) Abnormal pruning is implicated in autism (insufficient pruning) and schizophrenia (excessive pruning).

questions.question: The autonomic nervous system (ANS) has two main divisions with opposing effects on most organs. Which statement correctly describes the sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions?
options: Sympathetic neurons release acetylcholine at target organs; parasympathetic neurons release norepinephrine
The sympathetic division originates only from the brain, not the spinal cord
Both divisions always have identical effects on the same organ
Sympathetic preganglionic neurons are short and synapse in ganglia near the spinal cord; parasympathetic preganglionic neurons are long and synapse in ganglia near or within target organs
questions.explanation: The sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions differ in: (1) Anatomy—sympathetic: short preganglionic neurons from thoracolumbar spinal cord (T1-L2) → paravertebral or prevertebral ganglia → long postganglionic neurons to target. Parasympathetic: long preganglionic neurons from brainstem cranial nerves (III, VII, IX, X) and sacral spinal cord (S2-S4) → ganglia near or within target organs → short postganglionic neurons. (2) Neurotransmitters—both use ACh for preganglionic neurons. Postganglionic: sympathetic releases norepinephrine (exception: sweat glands use ACh), parasympathetic releases ACh. (3) Effects are generally antagonistic: sympathetic = 'fight or flight' (increased heart rate, dilated pupils, bronchodilation); parasympathetic = 'rest and digest' (decreased heart rate, constricted pupils, increased digestion).

questions.question: The reticular activating system (RAS) in the brainstem plays a critical role in:
options: Regulating arousal, wakefulness, and consciousness by sending excitatory projections to the thalamus and cerebral cortex
Coordinating voluntary movement
Producing cerebrospinal fluid
Controlling reflexive eye movements only
questions.explanation: The reticular activating system (RAS) is a network of nuclei in the brainstem reticular formation (extending from the medulla through the pons to the midbrain) that maintains consciousness and alertness. Key features: (1) Ascending projections through the thalamus to the cerebral cortex produce cortical arousal (EEG desynchronization). (2) Damage to the RAS causes coma, while its stimulation produces arousal from sleep. (3) Neurotransmitters involved include: acetylcholine (from pedunculopontine nucleus), norepinephrine (from locus coeruleus), serotonin (from raphe nuclei), dopamine (from ventral tegmental area), and histamine (from tuberomammillary nucleus). (4) Anesthetic agents act partly by suppressing RAS activity.

questions.question: Glial-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) and brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) are important for neuronal survival and function. During development, which process selects which neurons survive based on competition for limited neurotrophic factors?
options: Programmed cell death (apoptosis) of neurons that fail to receive adequate trophic support from their target tissues
Myelination
Neuronal migration
Axon guidance by netrin and semaphorin
questions.explanation: During nervous system development, many more neurons are produced than needed. The neurotrophic theory proposes that target tissues produce limited amounts of neurotrophic factors (NGF, BDNF, NT-3, GDNF), and neurons must compete for access to these factors. Neurons that successfully innervate targets and receive sufficient trophic support survive; those that fail to connect properly or receive inadequate trophic factor undergo apoptosis (programmed cell death). Approximately 50% of neurons produced during development die by apoptosis. This matching mechanism ensures: (1) appropriate neuron-to-target ratios, (2) elimination of incorrectly connected neurons, and (3) proper sizing of neuronal populations. Neurotrophins bind to Trk receptors, activating survival signaling pathways (PI3K/Akt, Ras/MAPK).

questions.question: A researcher wants to map the functional connectivity between the prefrontal cortex and amygdala in awake, behaving mice during a decision-making task. Which technique would provide the best combination of cell-type specificity and temporal resolution?
options: Structural MRI to identify anatomical connections

Simultaneous fiber photometry using genetically encoded calcium indicators (GCaMP) expressed in specific cell types in both regions, allowing real-time monitoring of population activity during behavior
Post-mortem histological staining of neural pathways
Single-unit recording with non-specific electrodes in one region
questions.explanation: Fiber photometry with genetically encoded indicators is optimal for this question: (1) Cell-type specificity: GCaMP (calcium indicator) or other genetically encoded sensors can be expressed in specific cell populations using Cre-driver lines (e.g., CaMKII-Cre for excitatory neurons, PV-Cre for parvalbumin interneurons). (2) Temporal resolution: Fiber photometry provides sub-second temporal resolution sufficient for capturing neural dynamics during decision-making. (3) Dual-site recording: Optical fibers implanted in both PFC and amygdala allow simultaneous monitoring of both regions during behavior. (4) Awake behaving animals: The technique is compatible with freely moving mice performing tasks. (5) Alternative approaches: fMRI has poor temporal resolution and no cell-type specificity; post-mortem analysis cannot capture dynamics; non-specific electrodes lack cell-type specificity. More advanced approaches like multi-fiber photometry arrays, miniscopes, or Neuropixels probes with optogenetic tagging could provide single-neuron resolution with cell-type identification.

questions.question: A patient has a lesion in the right posterior parietal cortex. They neglect objects in the left visual field, fail to dress the left side of their body, and draw only the right side of clocks. What is this condition?
options: Broca's aphasia
Parkinson's disease
Blindness in both eyes
Hemispatial neglect (contralateral neglect syndrome)
questions.explanation: Hemispatial neglect (also called unilateral neglect or contralateral neglect) is a neurological condition, most commonly after right posterior parietal cortex damage (especially inferior parietal lobule and temporoparietal junction), where patients fail to attend to or be aware of stimuli in the contralesional (left) hemispace. They may: eat food from only the right side of a plate, shave only the right side of the face, draw only the right side of objects, and deny that their left arm belongs to them (anosognosia). Neglect is more common and severe with right hemisphere damage because spatial attention is more lateralized to the right hemisphere, which attends to both sides, while the left hemisphere primarily attends to the right.

questions.question: Addiction involves hijacking of the brain's reward circuitry. The mesolimbic dopamine pathway, central to reward processing, originates in the:
options: Cerebellum and projects to the motor cortex
Hippocampus and projects to the hypothalamus
Ventral tegmental area (VTA) of the midbrain and projects to the nucleus accumbens in the ventral striatum, prefrontal cortex, and amygdala
Locus coeruleus and projects to the cerebral cortex
questions.explanation: The mesolimbic dopamine pathway is central to reward and addiction: (1) Origin: Dopaminergic neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) of the midbrain. (2) Projections: Nucleus accumbens (NAc) in the ventral striatum—the primary "reward center"; prefrontal cortex (PFC)—decision-making and impulse control; amygdala—emotional associations; hippocampus—contextual memory. (3) Natural rewards (food, sex, social interaction) transiently increase dopamine release in the NAc. (4) Drugs of abuse hijack this system: cocaine blocks the dopamine transporter (DAT), amphetamine reverses DAT to release dopamine, opioids disinhibit VTA dopaminergic neurons by inhibiting GABAergic interneurons, nicotine directly activates VTA neurons via nicotinic ACh receptors. (5) Addiction involves: tolerance (reduced response requiring more drug), dependence (withdrawal symptoms), and compulsive drug-seeking despite negative consequences. (6) Long-term changes include altered synaptic plasticity in the NAc and PFC, and reduced D2 receptor density.

questions.question: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) selectively degenerates motor neurons. The disease affects both upper motor neurons (in the motor cortex) and lower motor neurons (in the brainstem and spinal cord). What combination of symptoms distinguishes ALS from a pure upper motor neuron or pure lower motor neuron disease?
options: Only sensory deficits without motor impairment

ALS uniquely presents with both upper motor neuron signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron signs (muscle atrophy, fasciculations, hyporeflexia) in the same patient, often in different body regions simultaneously
Complete loss of consciousness with preserved motor function
Exclusively autonomic dysfunction without somatic motor involvement
questions.explanation: ALS demonstrates mixed UMN and LMN pathology: (1) Upper motor neuron (UMN) degeneration produces: spasticity (increased muscle tone), hyperreflexia (exaggerated stretch reflexes), and Babinski sign (extensor plantar response)—because descending inhibitory control of spinal reflexes is lost. (2) Lower motor neuron (LMN) degeneration produces: muscle weakness and atrophy (denervation atrophy), fasciculations (spontaneous firing of denervated motor units), fibrillations (on EMG), and eventually hyporeflexia/areflexia in severely denervated segments. (3) The hallmark of ALS is the co-occurrence of both UMN and LMN signs, which is unique among motor neuron diseases. (4) Progression: Symptoms typically begin focally (limb or bulbar onset) and spread to other regions. Respiratory muscle involvement is the usual cause of death (median survival 3-5 years). (5) Sensory neurons, oculomotor neurons, and autonomic neurons are relatively spared. (6) ~10% of cases are familial, with mutations in SOD1, C9orf72, TDP-43, and FUS being most common.
